title: An overview on *dformula*
text: dformula allows easily modify, transform, add extrapolate using basic R formula. operations data following: formula composed two part: \[ column\_names \sim new\_variables \] right-hand side shows names columns data left-hand side transformation new variables insert data. () used right-hand side indicate type transformation existing variable. function, can insert logical statement, function implemented R user build function. example: \[ var\_name_1 + var\_name_2 \sim (log(var\_name_1)) + (var\_name_2 == "something") \] two variable \(var_name_1\) \(var_name_2\) transformed \(log(var_name_1)\) selected equal \("something"\). fashion SQL, argument, input data, argument, new name variables, transformation, selection addition.  CRAN version can loaded development version GitHub: data available package used overview describes Population Area world countries
code: library('dformula') remotes::install_github('serafinialessio/dformula') data("population_data") pop_data <- population_data str(pop_data) ## 'data.frame':    159 obs. of  3 variables: ##  $ Country   : chr  "China" "India" "United States" "Indonesia" ... ##  $ Population: num  1.44e+09 1.38e+09 3.31e+08 2.74e+08 2.21e+08 ... ##  $ Area      : num  9388211 2973190 9147420 1811570 771 ...

title: An overview on *dformula*
text: add() function inserts new variables starting existing columns data. Suppose want calculate population density attach original dataset give name new variable Multiple variable can added single formula new names one transformation applied group variables, specify function multiple times new column names Suppose want add numerical id countries beginning dataset, using position argument can also add constant variable. example year observation C() construct add constant rows can interested dummy variable, .e. variable equal \(1\) event happen \(0\) otherwise. example, suppose build dummy variables populated countries. suppose countries \(100\) million people. two variables one populated countries biggest extended countries variable indicating populated biggest countries togheter want obtain boolean vector, interrogation, setting TRUE argument logic_convert function return boolean vector

title: An overview on *dformula*
text: transform() function modifies existing variables dataset. Suppose want change scale Population want logarithmic transformation, renaming variable single formula multiple variables can transformed, showed . can also transformed multiple variables multiple transformations
code: new_pop <- transform(from = pop_data,                       formula =  Population ~ I(Population/10000)) head(new_pop) ##         Country Population       Area ## 1         China  143932.38 9388211.00 ## 2         India  138000.44 2973190.00 ## 3 United States   33100.27 9147420.00 ## 4     Indonesia   27352.36 1811570.00 ## 5      Pakistan   22089.23     770.88 ## 6        Brazil   21255.94 8358140.00 new_pop <- transform(from = pop_data,                       formula =  Population ~ I(log(Population)),                       as = "log_pop") head(new_pop) ##                                     ## 1         China 21.08744 9388211.00 ## 2         India 21.04535 2973190.00 ## 3 United States 19.61764 9147420.00 ## 4     Indonesia 19.42690 1811570.00 ## 5      Pakistan 19.21319     770.88 ## 6        Brazil 19.17473 8358140.00 new_pop <- transform(from = pop_data,                       formula =  Population  + Area~ I(log())) head(new_pop) ##         Country Population      Area ## 1         China   21.08744 16.054965 ## 2         India   21.04535 14.905146 ## 3 United States   19.61764 16.028982 ## 4     Indonesia   19.42690 14.409704 ## 5      Pakistan   19.21319  6.647533 ## 6        Brazil   19.17473 15.938746 new_pop <- transform(from = pop_data,                       formula =  Population + Area ~ I(Population > 100000000) + I(log(Area))) head(new_pop) ##         Country Population      Area ## 1         China          1 16.054965 ## 2         India          1 14.905146 ## 3 United States          1 16.028982 ## 4     Indonesia          1 14.409704 ## 5      Pakistan          1  6.647533 ## 6        Brazil          1 15.938746

title: An overview on *dformula*
text: rename() function may used change names existing variables, example multiple variables
code: new_pop <- rename(from = pop_data, formula =  Population  ~ pop ) head(new_pop) ##         Country        pop       Area ## 1         China 1439323776 9388211.00 ## 2         India 1380004385 2973190.00 ## 3 United States  331002651 9147420.00 ## 4     Indonesia  273523615 1811570.00 ## 5      Pakistan  220892340     770.88 ## 6        Brazil  212559417 8358140.00 new_pop <- rename(from = pop_data, formula =  Population  + Area ~ pop + area) head(new_pop) ##         Country        pop       area ## 1         China 1439323776 9388211.00 ## 2         India 1380004385 2973190.00 ## 3 United States  331002651 9147420.00 ## 4     Indonesia  273523615 1811570.00 ## 5      Pakistan  220892340     770.88 ## 6        Brazil  212559417 8358140.00

title: An overview on *dformula*
text: fashion SQL, select() function first select rows, given statement, shows select variables. first part formula columns select, previous functions, right-hand side formula, condition part, select rows. Suppose want select populated countries can also add . returns variables instead nothing. want name populated countries might interest populated biggest countries selecting names
code: new_pop <- select(from = pop_data,                    formula =  . ~ I(Population > 100000000)) head(new_pop) ##         Country Population       Area ## 1         China 1439323776 9388211.00 ## 2         India 1380004385 2973190.00 ## 3 United States  331002651 9147420.00 ## 4     Indonesia  273523615 1811570.00 ## 5      Pakistan  220892340     770.88 ## 6        Brazil  212559417 8358140.00 new_pop <- select(from = pop_data,                    formula =  Country ~ I(Population > 100000000)) head(new_pop) ##         Country ## 1         China ## 2         India ## 3 United States ## 4     Indonesia ## 5      Pakistan ## 6        Brazil new_pop <- select(from = pop_data,                 formula = . ~ I(Population > 100000000 & Area > 8000000))  head(new_pop) ##         Country Population     Area ## 1         China 1439323776  9388211 ## 3 United States  331002651  9147420 ## 6        Brazil  212559417  8358140 ## 9        Russia  145934462 16376870 new_pop <- select(from = pop_data,                 formula = ~ I(Population > 100000000 | Area > 8000000))  head(new_pop) ##         Country Population       Area ## 1         China 1439323776 9388211.00 ## 2         India 1380004385 2973190.00 ## 3 United States  331002651 9147420.00 ## 4     Indonesia  273523615 1811570.00 ## 5      Pakistan  220892340     770.88 ## 6        Brazil  212559417 8358140.00 new_pop <- select(from = pop_data,                 formula = Country ~ I(Population > 100000000 | Area > 8000000))  head(new_pop) ##         Country ## 1         China ## 2         India ## 3 United States ## 4     Indonesia ## 5      Pakistan ## 6        Brazil

title: An overview on *dformula*
text: remove() function syntax select() function, now rows columns removed.
code: new_pop <- remove(from = pop_data,                    formula =  Area ~ I(Population > 100000000)) head(new_pop) ##     Country Population ## 15  Vietnam   97338579 ## 16    Congo   89561403 ## 17   Turkey   84339067 ## 18     Iran   83992949 ## 19  Germany   83783942 ## 20 Thailand   69799978

title: An overview on *dformula*
text: functions, except rename, argument na.remove remove rows missing values, adding, transforming selecting rows. remove function, can employed remove rows least missing observation, interested focus observation missing values, na.return = TRUE arguments select function return incomplete rows selection
code: data("airquality") dt <- airquality  dt_new <- remove(from = dt,formula = .~., na.remove = TRUE) head(dt_new) ##   Ozone Solar.R Wind Temp Month Day ## 1    41     190  7.4   67     5   1 ## 2    36     118  8.0   72     5   2 ## 3    12     149 12.6   74     5   3 ## 4    18     313 11.5   62     5   4 ## 7    23     299  8.6   65     5   7 ## 8    19      99 13.8   59     5   8 dt_new <- select(from = dt,formula = ~ I(Temp > 50), na.return = TRUE) head(dt_new) ##    Ozone Solar.R Wind Temp Month Day ## 5     NA      NA 14.3   56     5   5 ## 6     28      NA 14.9   66     5   6 ## 10    NA     194  8.6   69     5  10 ## 11     7      NA  6.9   74     5  11 ## 25    NA      66 16.6   57     5  25 ## 26    NA     266 14.9   58     5  26

title: Authors and Citation
text: Alessio Serafini. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Serafini (2023). dformula: Data Manipulation using Formula. R package version 1.0, https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=dformula.
code: @Manual{,   title = {dformula: Data Manipulation using Formula},   author = {Alessio Serafini},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 1.0},   url = {https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=dformula}, }

title: Data Manipulation using Formula
text: tool manipulating data using generic R function formula.

title: Data Manipulation using Formula
code: install.packages("dformula")

title: Data Manipulation using Formula
code: library(remotes) install_github("serafinialessio/dformula")

title: Data Manipulation using Formula
code: library(dformula)

title: Data Manipulation using Formula
text: overview

title: Add variables — add
text: Add new variables mutating input variables using formula.

title: Add variables — add
code: add(from, formula, as = NULL,     position = c("right", "left"),     na.remove = FALSE, logic_convert = TRUE,...)

title: Add variables — add
text: data.frame object variables formula formula indicating operation create new varibles. Look detail section explanantion. character vector names new variables. position new varaibles positioned begining (right) left (left) data input. na.remove logical value indicating whether NA values removed. logic_convert logical value indicating new logical varaible convertet 0 1 ... arguments

title: Add variables — add
text: formula composed two part: ~ new_variables right-hand new varaible add starting existing varaibles, using () function. example: ~ (log(column_names1)) + (column_names2/100) column_names1 log(column_names1) added data. na.remove set ti TRUE, new variables created, added dataset input observation missing removed.

title: Add variables — add
text: Returns data.frame object original new varaibles.

title: Add variables — add
text: Alessio Serafini

title: World population — population_data
text: World population countries

title: World population — population_data
code: data("population_data")

title: World population — population_data
text: data frame 159 observations following 3 variables. Country character vector countries names Population numeric vector population Area numeric vector area counties

title: World population — population_data
text: https://www.worldometers.info

title: World population — population_data
code: data(population_data) str(population_data) #> 'data.frame':	159 obs. of  3 variables: #>  $ Country   : chr  "China" "India" "United States" "Indonesia" ... #>  $ Population: num  1.44e+09 1.38e+09 3.31e+08 2.74e+08 2.21e+08 ... #>  $ Area      : num  9388211 2973190 9147420 1811570 771 ...

title: Remove a subset — remove
text: Selects row varaibles remove specifing condition using formula.

title: Remove a subset — remove
code: remove(from, formula = .~., na.remove = FALSE, ...)

title: Remove a subset — remove
text: data.frame object variables formula formula indicating operation create new varibles. Look detail section explanantion. na.remove logical value indicating whether NA values removed. ... arguments

title: Remove a subset — remove
text: formula composed two part: column_names ~ rows_conditions left-hand side names column remove, right-hand operation remove rows, using () function. example: column_names1 + column_names2 ~ (column_names1 == "") + (column_names2 > 4) first row selected removed observation column_names1 equal observation column_names2 biggers 4, column_names1 column_names2 removed varaibles returned. na.remove set TRUE, subsetting observations missing removed.

title: Remove a subset — remove
text: Returns data.frame object without selected elements.

title: Remove a subset — remove
text: Alessio Serafini

title: Remove a subset — remove
code: data("airquality") dt <- airquality  head(remove(from = dt, formula = .~ I(Ozone > 10))) #>      Ozone Solar.R Wind Temp Month Day #> NA      NA      NA   NA   NA    NA  NA #> 9        8      19 20.1   61     5   9 #> NA.1    NA      NA   NA   NA    NA  NA #> 11       7      NA  6.9   74     5  11 #> 18       6      78 18.4   57     5  18 #> 21       1       8  9.7   59     5  21 head(remove(from = dt, formula = .~ I(Ozone > 10), na.remove = TRUE)) #>    Ozone Solar.R Wind Temp Month Day #> 9      8      19 20.1   61     5   9 #> 18     6      78 18.4   57     5  18 #> 21     1       8  9.7   59     5  21 #> 23     4      25  9.7   61     5  23 #> 73    10     264 14.3   73     7  12 #> 76     7      48 14.3   80     7  15 head(remove(from = dt, formula = Ozone ~ .)) #>   Solar.R Wind Temp Month Day #> 1     190  7.4   67     5   1 #> 2     118  8.0   72     5   2 #> 3     149 12.6   74     5   3 #> 4     313 11.5   62     5   4 #> 5      NA 14.3   56     5   5 #> 6      NA 14.9   66     5   6  head(remove(from = dt, formula = Ozone~ I(Ozone > 10))) #>      Solar.R Wind Temp Month Day #> NA        NA   NA   NA    NA  NA #> 9         19 20.1   61     5   9 #> NA.1      NA   NA   NA    NA  NA #> 11        NA  6.9   74     5  11 #> 18        78 18.4   57     5  18 #> 21         8  9.7   59     5  21 head(remove(from = dt, formula = Ozone + Wind~ I(Ozone > 10))) #>      Solar.R Temp Month Day #> NA        NA   NA    NA  NA #> 9         19   61     5   9 #> NA.1      NA   NA    NA  NA #> 11        NA   74     5  11 #> 18        78   57     5  18 #> 21         8   59     5  21  head(remove(from = dt, formula = Ozone + . ~ I(Ozone > 10))) #>      Ozone Solar.R Wind Temp Month Day #> NA      NA      NA   NA   NA    NA  NA #> 9        8      19 20.1   61     5   9 #> NA.1    NA      NA   NA   NA    NA  NA #> 11       7      NA  6.9   74     5  11 #> 18       6      78 18.4   57     5  18 #> 21       1       8  9.7   59     5  21 head(remove(from = dt, formula = Ozone + NULL ~ I(Ozone > 10))) #>      Solar.R Wind Temp Month Day #> NA        NA   NA   NA    NA  NA #> 9         19 20.1   61     5   9 #> NA.1      NA   NA   NA    NA  NA #> 11        NA  6.9   74     5  11 #> 18        78 18.4   57     5  18 #> 21         8  9.7   59     5  21

title: Rename variables — rename
text: Rename variables using formulas

title: Rename variables — rename
code: rename(from, formula, ...)

title: Rename variables — rename
text: data.frame object variables formula formula indicating operation create new varibles. Look detail section explanantion. ... arguments

title: Rename variables — rename
text: formula composed two part: column_names ~ new_variables_name left-hand side select columns change names, right-hand new names selected columns example: column_names1 + column_names2 ~ new_variables_name1 + new_variables_name2 name column 1 name column 2 changed  new_variables_name1 new_variables_name2

title: Rename variables — rename
text: original data.frame changed column names

title: Rename variables — rename
text: Alessio Serafini

title: Rename variables — rename
code: data("airquality") dt <- airquality  head(rename(from = dt, Ozone ~ Ozone1)) #>   Ozone1 Solar.R Wind Temp Month Day #> 1     41     190  7.4   67     5   1 #> 2     36     118  8.0   72     5   2 #> 3     12     149 12.6   74     5   3 #> 4     18     313 11.5   62     5   4 #> 5     NA      NA 14.3   56     5   5 #> 6     28      NA 14.9   66     5   6 head(rename(from = dt, Ozone + Wind ~ Ozone_new + Wind_new)) #>   Ozone_new Solar.R Wind_new Temp Month Day #> 1        41     190      7.4   67     5   1 #> 2        36     118      8.0   72     5   2 #> 3        12     149     12.6   74     5   3 #> 4        18     313     11.5   62     5   4 #> 5        NA      NA     14.3   56     5   5 #> 6        28      NA     14.9   66     5   6

title: Select a subset — select
text: Selects row varaibles specifing condition using formula.

title: Select a subset — select
code: select(from, formula = .~., as = NULL, na.remove = FALSE, na.return = FALSE,...)

title: Select a subset — select
text: data.frame object variables formula formula indicating operation create new varibles. Look detail section explanantion character vector names new variables. na.remove logical value indicating whether NA values removed na.return logical value indicating whether observation NA values shown ... arguments

title: Select a subset — select
text: formula composed two part: column_names ~ row_conditions left-hand side names column select, right-hand operations select rows, using () function. example: column_names1 + column_names2 ~ (column_names1 == "") + (column_names2 > 4) first rows selected observation column_names1 equal observation column_names2 biggers 4, column_names1 column_names2 returned. na.remove set TRUE, subsetting observations missing removed.

title: Select a subset — select
text: Returns data.frame object containing selected elements.

title: Select a subset — select
text: Alessio Serafini

title: Transform varibles — transform
text: Mutate input variables  using formula.

title: Transform varibles — transform
code: transform(from, formula, as = NULL,           na.remove = FALSE, logic_convert = TRUE, ...)

title: Transform varibles — transform
text: data.frame object variables formula formula indicating operation create new varibles. Look detail section explanantion. character vector names new variables. na.remove logical value indicating whether NA values removed. logic_convert logical value indicating new logical varaible converted 0 1 ... arguments

title: Transform varibles — transform
text: formula composed two part: column_names ~ trasformed_variables left-hand side names column transform, right-hand operations applied selected columns, using () function. example: column_names1 + column_names2 ~ (log(column_names1)) + (column_names2/100) column_names1 mutated log(column_names1) column_names2 divided 100. na.remove set TRUE,  variables mutaded, observation missing removed.

title: Transform varibles — transform
text: Returns original data.frame object mutaded varaibles.

title: Transform varibles — transform
text: Alessio Serafini
